Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Enzymatic Synthesis of Insect Pheromones
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research Phase II project is a breakthrough in insect control for the agricultural industry. Provivi, Inc. intends to develop biosynthesis technology for producing insect pheromones, with a dramatic reduction in the cost of goods sold compared to existing syntheses. This will enable the use of pheromones beyond niche markets such as fruits and nuts: the target market for Provivi?s pheromone products are large acreage row crops. By introducing pheromone-based control as an inexpensive alternative in these markets, we are meeting a growing demand as conventional insecticides are becoming increasingly incapable of protecting crops due to insect resistance, regulatory constraints, and detrimental effects on beneficial insects. The societal and environmental benefits of using pheromones are numerous: pheromones are considered the safest possible insecticides with respect to human food consumption as well as environmental impact. The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency has characterized them as low risk. Our pheromone products will benefit consumers by creating a safer food supply with lower chemical residues, growers by introducing an effective and novel pest control solution and the environment by reducing the chemical exposure to the ecosystem.

The objectives of this Phase II research project are to improve the selectivity and productivity of our prototype biocatalyst to target commercial performance, and to demonstrate pheromone synthesis from a cheap feedstock using this biocatalyst. PRovivi's proprietary biocatalyst utilizes a novel monooxygenase to catalyze a reaction not found in nature. The research product of this project will expand the scientific knowledge for this class of biocatalysts. Additionally, since this class of biocatalysts has not been optimized for commercial viability for the specific reaction of interest, this research program could provide impactful research learnings to achieve target commercial performance. These learnings include but are not limited to changes in the biocatalyst physiology, metabolic pathways and potential stress responses. This research could provide valuable knowledge for both commercial and academic biocatalysis research that utilize this class of biocatalysts.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Synthetically produced insect pheromones have the potential to become the foundation of insect control programs reducing dependence on conventional insecticides in major agricultural crops. Since they were first synthesized synthetically in the late 1950s, the application of insect pheromones have been shown to reduce insect populations through sensory disruption and subsequent reduction in mating frequency.  Their mode of action is uniquely species specific and non-cidal in nature. This method of insect management has enjoyed success in permanent crops worldwide, particularly in Washington State apple orchards where adoption rates are greater than 90%. The cost of synthetic pheromones remains high, with industrial scale active ingredient (AI) prices ranging from $500 to $15,000 per kg. High synthesis cost has prohibited widespread use of this sustainable technology beyond high-value specialty crops. Through our work in this research project, we have successfully developed novel biosynthesis technology for producing insect pheromones at lower costs. This breakthrough in reducing the cost of synthesizing pheromones allows their use as the foundation of modern day integrated pest management programs. The societal and environmental benefits of replacing conventional insecticides with pheromones are numerous. Pheromones are considered a safer alternative to traditional insecticides because they provide the opportunity to reduce residues in food and help to protect non-target organisms and beneficial insect populations. The USDA Organic Program lists insect pheromones as one of the few synthetic organic compounds allowed in organic crop production. Additionally, the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency has characterized pheromones as lower risk than conventional pesticides. Beyond the broader benefit to society this project and reduction in costs of producing pheromones, our research has enhanced general scientific knowledge for the use of an oleaginous microorganism to produce straight chain lepidoptera pheromones. Applying a combination of strain and process improvements, we have obtained a commercially viable process for reactions that have not previously been optimized for industrial production.

 


Last Modified: 03/13/2018
Modified by: Mike M Chen

This breakthrough in reducing the cost of synthesizing pheromones allows their use as the foundation of modern day integrated pest management programs.
